title: Task Specialization in Social Production Communities: The Case of Geographic Volunteer Work

Every revision that you do goes into a recent changes list which is publicly visible to everybody.
And so people can go and reward it just like how it happens in Wikipedia.
In fact, there are people who.
Reward.
Cases of private points like someone has added a point guard is my home and this guy goes on diverted saying that that's not what this is about an.
People sometimes find this system is novel and they just to try out.
They make some random edits and save it, which turns out to be bad.
An people have reported it.
So yes, the exact same reward mechanism exists.
I'm looking from Australian National University.
Very interesting talk.
I was wondering if specialization would change as your system and your data mature.
Namely if a popular area gets all the blocks almost all the blocks annotated, then in that particular area then the specialization would shift to something else.
So right now all our analysis have been has been map wide, so you bring up an interesting point as though in downtown Minneapolis area would it be?
Are there more block specialists versus some other area?
I don't know yet offhand.
My intuition is that block specialist would still be more than others, and that's simply because blocks are more crucial.
I'm not sure about other kinds of specialists.
For example in parks points are very important because they often mark places of where water fountains exist for you to drink water, which are probably not as important somewhere else so.
It was interesting.
I don't know the top of my head.
